bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 28, 1928

div1.p: Carter informs Russell that she has delivered the completed medical references for the History of Yellow Fever to Frost, although there are still a few references that she and Brown will continue to try to verify. She thanks Russell for the extension of Brown's salary through October and applauds Brown's dedication to the project.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 28, 1928
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
September 28, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
1: Your good letter of September 22nd. was awaiting me
here last Tuesday, on my return from Baltimore, where I am profoundly
thankful to state, I took the metal file-cases, containging the com-
poleted references for the History of Yellow Fever last Monday and turned
them over to Dr. Frost, who has begun the final editing of the MSS of
Father's Historyof Yellow Fever. This, of course, is a tremendous step
forward, really the beginning of the end, although, as I wrote you in
my tentative estimate of the time needed to finish the book, how long
it will take Dr. Frost to do this work depends on how much uninterrupted
time he can give it.

2: While Dr. Frost is doing this final edition, Miss Brown
and I have been, and will be, strenuously occupied in trying to verify
the comparatively few references we have not yet been able to complete.
We have already done a lot of work on all of them, but there are some
untried methods of approach, which naturally entail a lot of reading
and hard work.

3: In connection with the verification of references, I
am very grateful to Mr. Van Wesep for his help and kindness and am
writing to him personally on the subject. His letter, and enclosures,
came just before I left for Baltimore, hence in time for me to take
his verified references over to Dr. Frost.

3': A letter just received from Dr. Connor, from Brazil,
is also going to be a big help in clearing up his bibliography, as, just
as I had suspected, some of his statements quoted by Father, were per-
sonal communications and we would have lost much time looking for them
in print.

4: I wish also to gratefully acknowledge a letter, received
this morning, from Mr. Giletter, stating that it had been decided to
continue Miss Brown's salary through the month of October. I am deeply
gratified at this decision and I am sure that Miss Brown will also
much appreciate the recognition of her services implied in keeping her
on the October payroll, when after she had offered to work after
September 30th. without compensation. I feel the more glad of this
decision, because Miss Brown has always positively refused to let me
reimburse her for any unusual expenses incurred by herself in connec-
tion with our work: taxis for transportation of heavy files and valuable
books in rainy weather: trips to my apartment for night work etc. etc.,
although,save when it was a physical impossibility, I always attended to
the former myself.

Well, I've heard much speculation among my friends as to
whether I would finish the book or the book would finish me, but I
always intended to “hang on” until the end and, although I'll admit
there's not much left of me, there's even less left of the book--thank
God! Also, It will be worth all that it has cost, which is high
praise--even for it.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
